en-US.title: Hong Kong is redefining your wallet: the future of digital Hong Kong dollars and cross-border payments has begun
en-US.content:
Have you ever thought that in the future, when you travel to Hong Kong for shopping, or transfer money with friends in Hong Kong, you may no longer need to exchange currency or wait for the bank to process it. Just tap your phone and the money will go directly to the other party's account?

This is not science fiction, but a reality that the Hong Kong government is actively promoting. Moreover, the impact of this revolution goes far beyond Hong Kong itself.

Let me share with you three important developments happening in Hong Kong that will completely change our understanding of "money".

The first story: the birth of digital Hong Kong dollars

In March 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the "Stablecoin Regulatory Sandbox" program. It sounds very technical, but it is actually the government preparing for the "digital Hong Kong dollar".

What is the digital Hong Kong dollar? Imagine that you have an app on your phone, and the money in it is not a bank deposit, but a digital currency directly endorsed by the Hong Kong government. It has exactly the same value as the paper Hong Kong dollar, but it can be transferred instantly, used 24 hours a day, and cross-border without obstacles.

Currently, three institutions have participated in this sandbox program, including Standard Chartered Bank, Animoca Brands and Hong Kong Telecom. They are testing various application scenarios in preparation for the official launch.

It is expected that Hong Kong's stablecoin regulations will officially take effect in August 2025. This means that legal digital Hong Kong dollars will soon be available.

The second story: the landing of digital RMB in Hong Kong

What's more interesting is that Hong Kong officially launched the cross-border payment pilot of digital RMB in May 2024.

Now, Hong Kong residents can open a digital RMB wallet with a Hong Kong mobile phone number, directly recharge it through Hong Kong's "FPS" system, and then spend it at 10 million merchants in mainland China.

Think about what this means: when you go to Shenzhen to eat and shop, you don't need to exchange money or swipe a card. You can directly scan the code with your mobile phone to pay, using digital RMB, but recharging uses the Hong Kong banking system.

This is not just convenient, it is a seamless connection between two financial systems.

The third story: the breakthrough of the mBridge project

The most exciting thing is that Project mBridge, in which Hong Kong participated, reached the "minimum viable product" stage in June 2024.

What is this? This is a system jointly developed by the four central banks of China, Hong Kong, Thailand and the UAE, which allows the digital currencies of central banks of various countries to be directly converted and traded with each other.

Simply put, international transfers between banks used to go through a complex network of agent banks, which might take several days and have high fees. But with mBridge, central banks can trade directly with each other, which is completed instantly and at very low costs.

What does this mean for ordinary people?

Let me illustrate with three scenarios:

Scenario 1: Cheaper and faster cross-border remittances
If you need to send money to a friend working in Hong Kong, you may have to go to the bank, fill out forms, wait for several days, and pay high fees. In the future, you may only need to operate on your mobile phone, complete it in a few minutes, and the fees are negligible.

Scenario 2: Seamless cross-border consumption
When traveling to Hong Kong, you don't need to exchange Hong Kong dollars in advance, nor do you need to swipe your credit card to bear the exchange rate risk. Your digital Taiwan dollars can be directly spent in Hong Kong, and the system will automatically convert them into digital Hong Kong dollars at the real-time exchange rate.

Scenario 3: More transparent international trade
If you are in the import and export business, future payment settlements may become simpler, more transparent, and safer. No longer need to rely on the traditional letter of credit system, smart contracts can ensure automatic payment after the goods are delivered.

However, what should be paid attention to?

First, privacy issues. Every transaction of digital currency will be recorded, and the government can theoretically track every consumption you make. This is good for anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing, but it may be a challenge to personal privacy.

Second, technology dependence. When everything becomes digital, the stability and security of the system become extremely important. In case the system crashes or is attacked by hackers, the impact may be more serious than the traditional banking system.

Third, monetary sovereignty. When digital currencies of different countries begin to interconnect, this may affect the monetary policy autonomy of each country. Strong currencies may have a greater impact on weak currencies.

How should Taiwan prepare?

These developments in Hong Kong are both opportunities and challenges for Taiwan.

The opportunity is that we can learn from Hong Kong's experience and prepare our own digital New Taiwan dollar system in advance. Taiwan has a strong foundation in financial technology and is fully capable of keeping up with this trend.

The challenge is that if we act too slowly, we may be marginalized in the new financial landscape. Imagine if Hong Kong, Singapore, and South Korea all have efficient digital currency systems, while Taiwan is still using traditional bank transfers. Our competitiveness in international trade and financial services will be affected.

My advice is:

First, pay close attention to this trend. Digital currency is not a distant future, it is rapidly becoming a reality.

Second, improve your digital financial literacy. Understand what stablecoins are, what central bank digital currencies are, and what cross-border payments are. These will all be everyday concepts in the future.

Third, support the development of relevant policies and regulations. Taiwan needs to establish its own digital currency framework, which requires the joint efforts of the government, industry, and the public.

A broader perspective

These changes taking place in Hong Kong are actually part of the reconstruction of the global financial system.

We are witnessing the arrival of a new financial era in which money will become more digital, more instant, and more global. This is not just a technological advancement, but also a fundamental redesign of the financial infrastructure.

For individuals, this means greater convenience and efficiency, but it also requires us to have new knowledge and skills.

For enterprises, this means new business models and competitive landscapes.

For countries, this means new challenges to monetary sovereignty and financial security.

Hong Kong has already started. Will other places be far behind?

The future has already begun in Hong Kong. Are you ready?
